channel.title: Second Brain üß† on
channel.description: Recent content in Second Brain üß† on

item.title: People of Data Engineering
item.description: A list of the people of [[Data Engineering]]. [[Dipankar Mazumdar]]: Dremio - Apache Iceberg [[Maxime Beauchemin]]: Father of Data Engineering [[Mehdi Ouazza]]: Awesome written content, also now on YouTube.

item.title: Maxime Beauchemin
item.description: Maxime Beauchemin Creator of [[Apache Airflow]] and [[Apache Superset]]. Started as [[Business Intelligence]] Engineer and is working now at [[Preset]] (Superset as a Service).

item.title: Backfill
item.description: ‚ÄúBackfilling is where you see the difference between a data engineer and a great data engineer.‚Äù ‚Äî [[Christophe Blefari]] on LinkedIn

item.title: Writer's Block
item.description: As with [[Creativity vs Productivity]], I try to embrace the block and do some creative work instead. Writing is supposed to be hard.

item.title: GoatCounter
item.description: Easy web analytics. No tracking of personal data. GoatCounter is an open-source web analytics platform available as a free donation-supported hosted service or self-hosted app.

item.title: Website Analytics
item.description: There are a bunch of tools nowadays. Some come for free and some are open-source, some respect [[GDPR]] regulations, and some do not.

item.title: Learning Data Engineering
item.description: Bootcamps: Pipeline Academy - Data Engineering Coding Bootcamp in Berlin Data Engineering Bootcamp ‚Äì Take your data engineering career to the next level [[EcZachly Inc’s Bootcamp]] by [[Zach Wilson]] Learn Data Engineering with Courses & Coaching | Learn Data by [[Andreas Kretz]] Origin:

item.title: Open-Source Data Engineering Projects
item.description: This note is for data engineers and developers. Here are some open-source data engineering projects that you can explore: My Projects Real estate dagster pipeline: A practical data engineering project for processing real estate data.

item.title: Continuous Notes
item.description: I believe this is the essence of a [[Second Brain]] and the [[Future of Blogging]] of blogging. Instead of old blogs that hold a wealth of information but get outdated over time, continuous notes are updated frequently and, instead of losing value, win over time.

item.title: Future of Blogging
item.description: I think personal [[Second Brain]] below is the future of blogging. Notes or [[Zettel]]s are updated constantly, evolving, and hosted on plain [[Markdown]] files.

item.title: Managed Data Stacks
item.description: Managed DevOps for your [[Modern Data Stack]], navigating around [[Kubernetes]] and Cluster management. I think of it as lego blocks, that can be stacked together.

item.title: Y42
item.description: Mission Control for Your Data Pipelines. Y42 is the first fully managed Modern DataOps Cloud ‚Äî purpose-built for production-ready data pipelines on BigQuery and Snowflake.

item.title: Kubernetes - DevOps Engine
item.description: Kubernetes - DevOps Engine It‚Äôs a platform that allows you to run and orchestrate container workloads. Kubernetes has become the de-facto standard** for your cloud-native apps to (auto-)¬†scale-out and deploys your open-source zoo fast, cloud-provider-independent.

item.title: Plural.sh
item.description: Plural.sh is a unified application [[deployment]] platform that makes it easy to run [[Open Source]] software on [[Kubernetes]]. Instead of using [[Terraform]] to deploy to Kubernetes, which starts to make it complicated (with all Kubernetes) involved.

item.title: Restack.io
item.description: The simplest way to manage stacks of open source products on a production-ready [[Kubernetes]] cluster. Kind of a store where you chose your artifacts and restack will deploy it.

item.title: Stackable
item.description: The modular open source data platform: Popular data apps. K8s-native. Easy to deploy and run. Open source data stack as of [[2022-09-09]]:

item.title: Data Engineering
item.description: Data engineering is a term that has shifted over the years from a Database Admins (DBA), ETL Developer, and Business Intelligence Specialist and merged with Software Engineers to a [[Data Engineer]] with the growth of data made his title.

item.title: Smart Note Taking
item.description: Why is this important? Because without the¬†smart, you‚Äôll add more clutter to your system, leading to minor organization and more stress.

item.title: Other Public Second Brains
item.description: Besides what a [[Second Brain]] is and my [[Public Second Brain with Quartz]]. Here are some other good ones: Andy Matuschak Strikingloo - Luciano Strika David Gasquez Brandon Boswell jzhao.

item.title: Productivity
item.description: Productivity Using your time intentionally. It’s efficient and minimizes waste. For me has a lot to do with [[Personal Knowledge Management (PKM)]], but also goes deep into our life, that’s why my article about [[Personal Knowledge Management Workflow for a Deeper Life]] summarises it probably best up until this point.

item.title: Orchestrators
item.description: Orchestrators If you go one step further, let’s say you choose one of the above technologies, you will most probably run into the need to handle intermediate levels in between.

item.title: Rubiks Cube: How to solve it
item.description: What challenged me to solve one myself: There are so many possible configurations (over 43 quintillions) that it would be impossible to solve it by randomly turning the faces until it’s all done.

item.title: SELECT Insights - Bundling with Microsoft Fabric and Orchestration (#2)
item.description: Hello friends, A quick note before we start: I changed the name of this newsletter to “SELECT Insights” and changed the structure slightly.

item.title: April Newsletter 2023
item.description: Hello friends! Welcome to the new format of my newsletter! I aim to create a more informal space for updates and discussions on Data Engineering and other topics I explore as I create new content.

item.title: Newsletter SELECT Insights
item.description: About this Newsletter Welcome to SELECT Insights, your curated and DISTINCT üòâ gateway into the data ecosystem and the thought-provoking ideas that I’m currently exploring.

item.title: Public Second Brain with Quartz
item.description: I built a Public Second Brain with [[Quartz - Publish Obsidian Vault]]. I added a python script find-publish-notes.py to the Makefile to copy all my SecondBrain notes from my [[Obsidian]] Vault with the hashtag #publish and copy it into the Quartz git-repo.

item.title: Obsidian
item.description: Obsidian Obsidian is a [[Second Brain]] and note taking app. It is a powerful and extensible knowledge base that works on top of your local folder of plain text files.

item.title: vim
item.description: Vim is a text-based editor that is running in the terminal. Unlike other editors, Vim’s power is its [[Vim Language (and Motions)]].

item.title: Evidence - SQL with Markdown
item.description: [[Business Intelligence]] for Modern Data Teams ([[Modern Data Stack]]). Beautiful reports synced to your data with just [[SQL]] and [[Markdown]].

item.title: How to Write Well?
item.description: It’s hard, it’s painful as Stephen mentions in [[On Writing - Stephen King]] (especially [[On Writing - Stephen King#GOOD WRITING]]) and [[The Elements of Style - William Strunk Jr]].

item.title: What has Rust in common with DuckDB?
item.description: I’m constantly thinking about what [[Rust]] and [[DuckDB]] have in common. I’m constantly interchanging them when thinking about one or the other, but why?

item.title: Plaintext Files
item.description: Similar [[Markdown]], plaintext files are future-proof. Every device, including ones long gone, and ones not invented yet, can read and edit plain text.

item.title: Rich Text
item.description: The Rich Text Format is a proprietary document file format with published specifications developed by Microsoft Corporation from 1987 until 2008 for cross-platform document interchange with Microsoft products.

item.title: Taxonomy of note types
item.description: üö¶ My Statuses üì¨ Start any note, idea, something I read, or anything that comes to mind. Just some fleeting notes.

item.description: Arc from The Browser Company Feature Zap: Cool new feature to remove elements my Tweet YouTube by [[Brandon Boswell]]

item.title: Microsoft Fabric
item.description: New announcement [[2023-05-23]] about the single place of MS; it’s like a [[Databricks]] replica, except for the tools in [[Azure]] without needing to go into Azure (see more below).

item.title: Clarity
item.description: Clarity comes from having time to think, read and create! The outcome is finding YOUR truth and removing resistance more deeply.

item.title: SQL is declarative
item.description: [!question] Is SQL declarative? And why not imperative as you specify the from and every detail in the WHERE?

item.title: OneTable
item.description: Today [[2023-02-02]] [[Onehouse]] announced Onetable. Onehouse customers can now query their [[Apache Hudi]] tables as [[Delta Lake]] and [[Apache Iceberg]] unlocking native accelerations & advanced features inside Databricks and snowflake.

item.title: MS OneLake
item.description: MS OneLake Announced with [[Microsoft Fabric]] [[2023-05-23]] and it’s basically a wrapper around [[Delta Lake]] (for now). But they can also read from different Cloud providers such as AWS or Azure.

item.description: Pathless Path is from the book [[The Pathless Path (Paul Millerd)]]. The [[Pathless Path]] is experimenting on your own to find a life you want to live vs.

item.title: Fonts
item.description: I have a love for nice fonts. Reading and Writing Fonts Atkinson Hyperlegible (mentioned Your favourite fonts choice and why? thread - Share & showcase - Obsidian Forum ) iA Writer Quattro Inter - Default of [[Obsidian]] and used also at [[Airbyte]] website [[Fonts - DYSLEXIA]] which makes reading easier for people with problems (from [[Tobias Sch√§uble]]) Piazzolla, serif; from How to treat monospace alike fonts in a tech blog?

item.title: Markdown vs. Rich Text
item.description: [[Markdown]] is getting the de facto standard for content writing. It has many excellent features such as [[Admonition (Call-outs)]], [[Mermaid]], and Drawings, all with essential text files.

item.title: Quartz - Publish Obsidian Vault
item.description: Features Extremely fast natural-language¬†search Customizable and hackable design based on¬†[[GoHugo]] Automatically generated backlinks, link previews, and local graph Built-in¬†CJK + Latex Support¬†and¬†Admonition-style callouts ([[Admonition (Call-outs)]]) Support for both Markdown Links and Wikilinks Links GitHub Link - ü™¥ Quartz Page ([[Digital Garden]]) on Reddit: Quartz: Create and publish your Obsidian Vault for free!

item.title: Listmonk
item.description: Self-hosted newsletter and mailing list manager. Performance and features packed into a single binary. Free and open source. My new [[Newsletter]] is published with Listmonk on list.

item.title: Create a Book on Markdown
item.description: For creating a Book on top of [[Markdown]], there are some solutions I want to explore here. This could be done solely in [[Obsidian]], but there wouldn’t be management around chapters, post-processing and many other things that include a book.

item.title: Neovim
item.description: Text editor evolved from the old [[vim]]. People call it not [[IDE]], such as [[VSCode]] or similar, but [[PDE (Personalized Development Environment)]].

item.title: HackMD
item.description: [[Google Docs]] for [[Markdown]]. Effective team collaboration. HackMD¬†is a real-time, multi-platform collaborative Markdown editor. You can use HackMD to write notes with other people on your computer, tablet, or phone.

item.title: Markdown
item.description: As written by Derek Write plain text files | Derek Sivers and summarised in my [[Personal Knowledge Management Workflow for a Deeper Life]].

item.title: Computer Desk Setup (Todays Office)
item.description: Swipe through these images to see the progression of my desk setups over time, from side-by-side displays to an ultrawide and portrait combo, and finally to a single 27’’ or an extended laptop setup for meetings.

item.title: Map of Content (MOC)
item.description: As mentioned in the [[Taxonomy of note types]], the icon üó∫ indicates a Map of Content, MOC in short. These are meant to cluster the Zettelkasten notes into more prominent clusters, connecting the more significant ideas rather than individual notes.

item.title: What I have learned Abroad
item.description: Maybe you think to start 1-2 years abroad or traveling the world as well. Therefore I want to share what I learned from my recent experience.

item.title: Location Independent Lifestyle?
item.description: Firstly, what is location-independent work or a nomadic lifestyle? I would describe it as not being tied to a particular location for any reason.

item.title: Speed Reading
item.description: Key points from How to Speed Read by [[Tim Ferriss]]: Establish a baseline: Determine your words per minute (WPM) reading rate by counting the average number of words per line and lines per page in a standardized book.

item.title: How to Read Books
item.description: Tactical technique with skipping and choosing books on How to Read Faster by [[Mark Manson]]: Quiet the inner monologue Read with your finger Stop reading books you hate the point of reading is for you, don’t feel bad if you skip chapters or you don’t finish Schedule time to read Read more than one book at a time Purely reading faster can be done with [[Speed Reading]] techniques.

item.title: Deep Work
item.description: Deep Work Or also called flow. Introduced in the book [[Deep Work (Cal Newport)]]. TODO: Definiton of flow/deep work. How I get into Deep Work (Flow) Journal before going to bed what 1-2 tasks you must/want to achieve tomorrow.

item.description: The elephant in the room is today‚Äôs distractions, such as¬†social media apps that the most advanced technology companies make and Neuroscientists to make you¬†addicted.

item.title: Admonition (Markdown)
item.description: The¬†admonition,¬†also known as¬†call-outs, are shortcuts baked into most Markdown framework. It’s a nice way to include side content without significantly interrupting the reading flow.

item.title: Data Engineering Approaches
item.description: Because I encountered these bottlenecks myself, and more frequently lately, I asked myself, how can we: Make BI easier? Transparent for everyone?

item.title: Education is changing
item.description: Facebook, Airbnb, and other companies taking a step into so-called “Data Camps or Data University” to educate internal employees in respect of data to get more data savvy.

item.title: ETL is changing
item.description: Furthermore, the way we do ETL is changing as well, as [[Maxime Beauchemin]], data engineer at Airbnb quotes: _Product know-how on platforms like Informatica, IBM Datastage, Cognos, AbInitio or Microsoft SSIS isn‚Äôt common amongst modern data engineers, and being replaced by more generic software engineering skills along with understanding of programmatic or configuration driven platforms like Airflow, Oozie, Azkabhan or Luigi.

item.description: Writing has been my new job, at least part-time, since I joined [[Airbyte]]. So how to get better, and what about writing makes it so hard?

item.description: The default path is a ‚Äúscript‚Äù of decisions and accomplishments needed to be seen as a successful adult. For example good grades -> good job -> own a home -> have a family

item.description: IDEs are Developer Environments such as [[VSCode]], PyCharm, [[vim]], etc. An alternative term that comes from the [[Neovim]] community is called [[PDE (Personalized Development Environment)]].

item.description: Write valuable things to your readers! Don’t explain as in school. Don’t create new/original knowledge (if it’s not valuable, who cares?

item.title: Personal Knowledge Management Workflow for a Deeper Life - As a Computer Scientist
item.description: ![[Pasted image 20220330163737.png]] With burnout and mental stress at every level of our lives, I find my [[Personal Knowledge Management (PKM)]] system even more valuable.

item.title: Getting Things Done (GTD)
item.description: Up until now, we managed ideas and knowledge, which enlarges the [[Second Brain]] and how to link our thoughts. Besides this,¬†much anxiety and stress come from not being on top of your tasks, jobs, things you might want to do, ideas, and lists you want to read.

item.title: Creativity vs Productivity
item.description: Creativity and [[Productivity]] are two of the same thing. You can’t be creative without being productive. It’s a pendulum that goes forth and back.

item.title: Pre-Game Routine
item.description: In order to get into the habit, it can help to develop a habit before the habit. [[James Clear]] calls that the pre-game routine.

item.title: Annual Work Reflection 2022
item.description: üéÑ Soon is Christmas, and it’s always good to recap at the end of the year. The years always fly by like nothing, but a lot happened in the last year.

item.title: PDE (Personalized Development Environment)

item.description: A lifestyle I admire. Not really crazy to have only 15 items or so, but that is before you buy something that you need to sell.

item.description: Write the lessons learned. The mesmerizing content is the content shared, whether there is a return or not. You can either buy someone’s attention, or you can earn it.

item.title: Zettel
item.description: It’s the small individual idea in the [[Zettelkasten]] system. [[Niklas Luhmann]] started this and he wrote each idea on an index card organized inside the Zettelkasten.

item.description: As [[Obsidian]] Publish is great but expensive, I’m interested in an open-source solution that I can integrate into my blog.

item.title: New Tabs in Obsidian with version 1.0

item.title: Journaling
item.description: Another one that goes hand in hand with [[Stoic]] is¬†Journaling. It grounds me similarly to meditating. I always heard on the¬†[[Tim Ferriss]] Podcast¬†that ‚Äúsuccessful‚Äù people meditate and journal a lot.

item.title: Ultradian Rhythm
item.description: In chronobiology, an ultradian rhythm is a recurrent period or cycle repeated throughout a 24-hour day. In contrast, circadian rhythms complete one cycle daily, while infradian rhythms such as the human menstrual cycle have periods longer than a day.

item.title: Python
item.description: Python is a high-level, general-purpose programming language. Its design philosophy emphasizes code readability with the use of significant indentation. Python is dynamically-typed and garbage-collected.

item.title: What Makes a Happy Life
item.description: Besides [[Stoic|Stoicism]] and [[Journaling]], it‚Äôs relationships. According to the¬†most comprehensive study in happiness, the¬†happiest people are the ones having genuine relationships.

item.title: Literature Notes
item.description: The second is [[Literature Notes]]. [[Niklas Luhmann]] would write them down on index cards with the bibliographic details on the back.

item.title: Personal Knowledge Management (PKM)
item.description: The PKM workflow to capture knowledge and todo‚Äôs is essential for any human, developer,j or knowledge worker. It should reduce stress and improve your quality of life in a way you wouldn‚Äôt believe before you had one.

item.title: Deep Life
item.description: Deep life, and productivity on their own do not work. [[Cal Newport]]. Besides a sound [[Personal Knowledge Management (PKM)]], a place to store all your knowledge and handle your to-dos, much more is needed for a fulfilled life.

item.title: Data engineer job description and skills
item.description: If English is the language of business, SQL is the language of¬†data and Python is the language of engineering. While technology disappears often, SQL is still here.

item.title: When is a data engineer needed?
item.description: I believe, that not every company is in need of data engineers. His skills are mostly required if the company either:

item.title: The role of a data engineer
item.description: In order to get high-quality and frequently updated data sets, it is important to distinguish between data pipelines that are done and cleaned by data engineers and all the others that are mostly exploratory.

item.title: Email
item.description: A big part of everyone is email. Although I argue against email and instead propose¬†a way we (should) communicate, it‚Äôs still a big part of work or other areas of life.

item.title: Reading Books for a Happy Life
item.description: Instead of reading depressing news what will make you happy, is reading books. If you are not a bookworm or not reading generally, you won‚Äôt agree with this.

item.title: Routines such as Sports or Meditation
item.description: Many studies say that we should start a routine or it doesn’t stick. I’m not too good at this, but I try to do it primarily for my weekly sports, meditation, or writing habits.

item.title: Stop reading News
item.description: A long time ago, I stopped reading the news. Not reading the news doesn‚Äôt mean that I‚Äôm uninformed. But I stopped reading the newest, most attention-driven headline updated 100 times a day.

item.title: Permanent Notes
item.description: Permanent notes are the third type of note in the [[Zettelkasten]] system, and make up the long-term knowledge that gives the slip-box its value.

item.title: Zettelkasten
item.description: Zettelkasten Started by [[Niklas Luhmann]], also called “Slip Box”. This approach will further dilute the idea of a librarian who organizes books in main categories and sub-folder and focuses only on the thought at hand as an individual note.

item.title: Fleeting Notes
item.description: Fleeting notes are quick, informal notes on any thought or idea that pops your mind. They don‚Äôt need to be highly organized and shouldn‚Äôt be.

item.title: Linking Your Thinking (LYT)
item.description: Build a personal system to manage your knowledge: The Linking Your Thinking Workshop is an online workshop that will teach, train, and support you in building a [[Personal Knowledge Management (PKM)]] system you can trust.

item.title: The Building a Second Brain methodology will teach you how to:
item.description: The Building a Second Brain methodology will teach you how to: Consistently move your projects and goals to completion by organizing ahd accessing your knowledge in a results-oriented way Transform your personal knowledge into income, taking advantage of a rapidly growing knowledge economy Uncover unexpected patterns and connections between ideas Reduce stress and ‚Äúinformation overload‚Äù by expertly curating and managing your personal information stream Develop valuable expertise, specialized knowledge, and the skills to deploy it in a new job, career, or business Cultivate a collection of valuable knowledge and insights over time without having to follow rigid, time-consuming rules Unlock the full value of the wealth of learning resources all around you, such as online courses, webinars, books, articles, forums, and podcasts Most important take aways:
